Name: New York Marble Cemetery Entrance
Caption: Inscription the entrance of the New York Marble Cemetery, Manhattan's first public, non-secterian cemetery. Not to be confused with the New York City Marble Cemetery, the second public, non-secterian cemetery in New York, founded one year after.
Description: Color photo of inscription on top of the New York Marble Cemetery entrance door

Name: New York Marble Cemetery vaults wall
Caption: The New York Marble Cemetery was created in response to the yellow fever outbreak that started near the Trinity Church cemetery. The Common Council ruled to ban earth graves in lower Manhattan to limit the spread of the Caribbean-born disease. Instead, marble vaults were built ten feet underground. Names from the original vault owners are engraved on marble tablets that are set into the stone cemetery walls. These tablets act as a guide for the location of the vaults underground. In order to access a vault, a stone slab has to be exposed by digging by hand, that is then lifted off to expose the entry shaft going down to the slate doors. Some of the vaults also require a key to open the door.
Description: Color photo of a wall of vaults in the New York Marble Cemetery

Name: New York Marble Cemetery Marble Vaults
Caption: A vault tablet from the New York Marble Cemetery. The inscription is not clear but the first name seems to be "George Bowen" and "Richard B.Brown, who according to the New York Marble Cemetery's website were interred in 1848 and 1860, in vault 8. The website shows that around 16 people are interred in vault #8, most of which have the last name "Bowen"
Description: Color photo of a vault tablet in the New York Marble Cemetery
